A hollow nanoflower material CuCo2O4@NFs with abundant oxygen vacancies (VO) and cobalt vacancies (VCo) was prepared by a simple method. The novel material CuCo2O4@NFs showed excellent oxidation activity, cleaving the β-O-4 bond in lignin model compounds. Conversion of the substrate was as high as 99.02 %, and the yield of the main product, phenol, reached 49.50 %. Structural analysis showed that the petal and cavity form of the material increased its specific surface area, which facilitated its full contact with O2 molecules. Moreover, the VO generated by lattice oxygen detachment during annealing favor the adsorption of O2, and the VCo generated through lattice distortion induced by Cu-metal doping promoted the detachment of oxygen intermediates. The synergy of these two defects improved the rate of the rate-limiting step. Density functional theory calculations revealed that the synergistic effect of VO and VCo narrowed the gap between the Fermi energy levels and the d-band center, thereby enhancing electron mobility. Finally, excellent recyclability of CuCo2O4@NFs was confirmed through cycling experiments. The application of this material provided technical support for the efficient cracking of lignin into high-value-added chemicals and realized the effective utilization of woody biomass resources. Graphical Abstract Keywords Nanoflower Lignin cracking CuCo β-O-4 Oxygen vacancy Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Lignin has a wide range of applications in the chemical and materials fields [1]. It can be extracted for the preparation of high-value-added chemical products such as resins, coatings, paper, textiles, and bioplastics. These lignin-based products can replace traditional fossil fuel derivatives, which reduces environmental pollution and promotes sustainable development [2]. However, lignin is a macromolecular compound composed of multiple benzene ring monomers chemically bonded together [3,4]. This multimerized structure renders the bonds of lignin extremely tight and difficult to be broken by external decomposition agents or catalysts [5,6]. Studies have revealed that the β-O-4 bond is the most common linking unit in lignin, constituting about 50–70 % of the linkage bonds [7]. Therefore, breakage of the β-O-4 bond can promote the cleavage and degradation of lignin. Currently, catalytic hydrogenation [8–10], oxidative catalysis [11–13], high-temperature pyrolysis [14], and microbial degradation [15] are available for cleavage of the β-O-4 bond. Of these, oxidative catalysis under mild conditions, offering high selectivity, has received much attention. In the core mechanism of oxidative catalysis given in the literature, Cα-OH is oxidized to Cα=O by oxygen radicals on the lignin molecule to afford an aldehyde or ketone intermediate [16]. The β-O-4 bond dissociation energy of the aldehyde or ketone intermediate is significantly lower than that of the substrate, which facilitates the rapid conversion of lignin into high-value-added products. The production of oxygen radicals is clearly the rate-limiting step of the reaction. The design of catalysts capable of generating sufficient quantities of oxygen radicals in a relatively short period of time represents a significant research priority. Bimetallic-loaded alloy catalysts show excellent performance in this regard. For example, Chen et al. prepared CS-modified CuCoN catalysts by using a controlled “precursor-pre-selection” method [17]. Their analysis demonstrated that the specific active sites between the CuCo diatoms facilitated suitable binding with favorable ΔG O* in the oxidation reaction, which improved the oxidation efficiency. Repeated experiments revealed that the limited specific surface area of the CuCoN material prevented the active sites from being fully exposed. Nevertheless, micron and nanoscale hollow nanoflower (NF) materials serve as exceptional functional materials providing high specific surface area for surface-catalyzed multiphase reactions [18]. For example, Jing et al. reported a 3D MoS x /Zn3In2S6 NF material that oxidized 97.52 % of the lignin model compound 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol to 2-phenoxyacetophenone [19]. The material exhibited good selectivity, and its catalytic properties were improved by modifying the morphology and composition. Unfortunately, a prerequisite for high selectivity was that the reaction had to be carried out under argon or vacuum. Further enhancement of the catalytic activity is necessary to achieve effective breakage of β-O-4 bonds under mild conditions. It was discovered that VO and metal vacancies can act as electron trapping sites to modulate the coordination structure as well as the electronic state of surface adsorbates for the formation of surface reactive oxygen species [20]. For example, Zhang et al. prepared Ni-Cu/Nb2O5@Fe3O4 with Ni-Cu alloy and VO for catalytic birch lignin cleavage [8]. Their experimental results showed that this catalyst could convert 85 % of birch lignin and produce 58 % of monophenols under mild reaction conditions. Although the conversion and main product yield reached good levels, there is still room for improvement. The main task at this stage is to further enhance the conversion of the substrate and the yield of the main product by modulating the type and number of defects. In view of the above considerations, we used solvothermal synthesis and high temperature annealing to synthesize CuCo2O4@NFs nanoflower materials. The apparent morphology of the material was characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Its structure was characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray absorption fine structure (XAFS) spectroscopy, Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), and thermogravimetry (TG). This characterization confirmed that the material had a high specific surface area as well as abundant VO and VCo. Furthermore, optimization of the VO and VCo concentrations was achieved by adjusting the metal:2-methylimidazole ratio and the annealing temperature, which further improved the activity of the material. The optimized CuCo2O4@NFs exhibited excellent activity in the oxidative breakage of β-O-4 bonds. Finally, the reaction kinetics of the process was analyzed by density functional theory (DFT) calculations to reveal the mechanism. This work has implications for the design and development of catalysts for efficient cleavage of the β-O-4 bond of lignin. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Chemicals The 5,5-dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO), 2,2,6,6-tetramethylpiperidine oxide (TEMPO), and alkali lignin were purchased from Macklin. Other materials mentioned in the text were purchased from Lanten Pharmaceuticals, Inc. All of the reagents applied in the experiments were commercially available and used without further treatment. 2.2 Preparation process of CuCo/ZIF-67 samples First, cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (1.75 g) and copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.24 g) were combined with methanol (180 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 1 h to obtain mixed Solution A. Next, 2-methylimidazole (3.94 mg) was dissolved in methanol (50 mL) and stirred at room temperature for 1 h to obtain homogeneous Solution B. Solutions A and B were combined in a slow, steady manner at 25°C. The resulting mixture was stirred for 2 h and then left to stand for 24 h. Finally, the purple solid product was collected by centrifugation and washed several times with methanol and deionized water. CuCo/ZIF-67 samples were obtained by drying at 80°C for 24 h. 2.3 Preparation process of CuCo2O4@NF samples CuCo/ZIF-67 (0.3 g), prepared by the aforementioned method, was dissolved in methanol (50 mL) to obtain Solution A′. Cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate (1.82 g) and copper(II) nitrate trihydrate (0.25 g) were dissolved in methanol (50 mL) to obtain solution B′. Solution A′ was combined with Solution B′, and the resulting mixture was transferred to a stainless steel autoclave lined with polytetrafluoroethylene and maintained at 120°C for 1 h. The mixture was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, whereupon the brown solid product was collected by centrifugation and washed repeatedly with deionized water and methanol. The product was first dried in a vacuum drying oven at 80°C for 24 h and then calcined at 210°C for 0.5 h (attained at a heating rate of 5°C min–1) to obtain the final product CuCo2O4@NFs. 2.4 Preparation process of Co3O4@NFs samples The procedure was as described for the preparation of CuCo2O4@NFs, but with the omission of copper(II) nitrate trihydrate. 2.5 Preparation process of CuO@NFs samples The procedure was as described for the preparation of CuCo2O4@NFs, but with the omission of cobalt(II) nitrate hexahydrate. 2.6 Oxidation experiment The 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol (2.14 g), catalyst (0.32 g), and methanol (50 mL) were placed in an autoclave. The autoclave was then turned-off and a purging operation was performed 2–3 times with O2. Thereafter, the kettle was filled with O2 at 1 MPa for the reaction, which involved placing the autoclave in an oil bath, setting the reaction temperature at 140°C for a duration of 6 h, with a rotational speed of 600 rpm. After the reaction, the reactor was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. 2.7 Product analysis The solid-liquid mixture in the kettle was separated, and the solid product was washed several times and then dried prior to use in catalyst recycling experiments. The liquid products were diluted with tetrahydrofuran and analyzed by high-performance liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry (HPLC-MS). The formulae for feedstock conversion, product yield, and product selectivity for oxidation of the lignin model compound 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol are given below: (1) C = C initial − C final C initial × 100 % (2) S = C product C initial − C final × 100 % (3) Y = C × S × 100 % where C represents the feedstock conversion rate, C initial represents the initial concentration of the feedstock, C final represents the remaining concentration of the feedstock, S represents the product selectivity, C product represents the concentration of a certain product, and Y represents the product yield. Characterization: Nitrogen adsorption-desorption experiments were carried out using the BET model on a Mack TriStar II 3flex apparatus at 300°C that had been pre-purged with nitrogen for 2 h. EPR spectroscopy was performed at room temperature on a Bruker EPR EMXplus apparatus, with DMPO and TEMPO as free radical trapping agents. SEM (Hitachi Regulus 8100) and TEM (FEI Tecnai F20) were used to analyze the apparent morphologies of the materials. The accelerating voltage was 10 kV for SEM inspection and 200 kV for TEM inspection. The product was characterized by HPLC-MS on a Shimadzu LC-MS-2020 apparatus equipped with an ultraviolet detector and a C18 column operated at a flow rate of 0.8 mL min–1 at 30℃, with a detection wavelength of 290 nm and a mobile phase of methanol/glacial acetic acid (3:7, v/v). The crystalline phase composition of the materials was characterized by XRD (X′Pert PRO MPD), employing Cu-K α radiation. The 2θ range was 10–80°, scanned at a rate of 0.05° s–1. The elemental composition of the material was determined by XPS (Thermo K-alpha). Mg-K α X-rays were used as the excitation source. XAFS spectra were measured at 1W1B station on an easyXAFS300 apparatus operated at 2.5 GeV with a maximum current of 250 mA. The instrument was equipped with a silicon drift detector. The acquired EXAFS data were processed according to standard procedures using the ATHENA module implemented in the IFEFIT software package; k2-weighted EXAFS spectra were obtained by subtracting the post-edge background from the total absorption and then normalized with respect to the edge-jump step. Inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer Optima 5300 DV Series ICP-MS system, and all carbon-containing samples were tested after complete dissolution in nitric acid. Temperature-programmed desorption of oxygen (O2-TPD) was performed on an automated chemical adsorption apparatus (BelCata II, Japan). Raman spectra were acquired on a LabRam HR Evolution instrument. In situ Fourier-transform infrared (in situ FTIR) testing in attenuated total reflection (ATR) mode was performed on a Thermo IS 50 spectrometer. 2.8 DFT calculations Based on DFT, all computational procedures were performed with the CASTEP module of the Materials Studio software package [21]. Calculations were performed based on the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) generalization under the generalized gradient approximation (GGA), and interactions between individual atoms were described using a plane-wave ultrasoft pseudopotential approach. The Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shanno algorithm was chosen for minimization tests. The unit cell with group space Fd3m consisted of 36 Co atoms and 48 O atoms, and in each cell one atom was removed from the defective model. All atoms were relaxed until the Hermann–Feynman force on each of them was reduced to less than 0.02 eV Å−1. [22] 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Composition and morphology analysis of CuCo2O4@NFs The CuCo2O4@NFs catalyst was synthesized in two steps (comprising a simple chemical reaction method and a solvothermal method), and included the preparation of the CuCo/ZIF-67 precursor and the growth of nanoflowers ( Fig. 1a). The microstructures of the materials during the synthesis were studied by SEM and TEM. ZIF-67 has a typical rhombic dodecahedral shape with flat, smooth, and angular surfaces (Fig. 1b, c). The rhombic particles were approximately 100 nm in size with a cavity structure (Fig. 1d, e). Elemental mapping of CuCo/ZIF-67 showed that the surface consisted mainly of Co, Cu, and C, with a small amount of O (Fig. 1f–i). The CuCo/ZIF-67 precursor was processed by solvothermal and high-temperature annealing methods to obtain the CuCo2O4@NFs composite. This material consisted of nanoflowers composed of a large number of petal structures stacked together, with an average particle size increased to 127 nm (Fig. 1j). Fig. 1k shows that each petal was about 20 nm long and 17 nm wide. Fig. 1l shows that CuCo2O4@NFs retained the cavity structure of the precursor with a size of about 100 nm. Fig. 1m shows that the wall thickness between the petal and the cavity was about 10 nm. Elemental mapping of CuCo2O4@NFs revealed a high degree of overlap of Co, Cu, and O within the material (Fig. 1n–q). This observation indicated the presence of substantial quantities of Co3O4 and CuO within the material, which is conducive to the formation of defects. The compositions and crystal structures of the CuCo/ZIF-67 and CuCo2O4@NFs materials were determined by XRD analysis (Figure S1). The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 35.7°, 38.9°, and 49.0° for both materials correspond to the (002), (111), and (202) crystal planes of CuO, respectively (PDF #45–0937) [23]. The diffraction peaks at 2θ = 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.8°, 44.8°, 59.3°, and 65.3° correspond to the (220), (222), (311), (400), (511), and (533) crystallographic surfaces of Co3O4, respectively (PDF #42–1467) [24]. The XRD data further corroborated the presence of Co3O4 and CuO in the material. 3.2 Oxidizing properties of CuCo2O4@NFs The oxidizing activities of various catalytic materials were compared using 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol as a model compound for the β-O-4 bond. Table 1 shows that the oxidation products of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol were mainly phenol (2a), acetophenone (3a), 2-hydroxyacetophenone (4a), and 1-methoxyethylbenzene (5a). Among the catalysts, the CuCo2O4@NFs material showed optimal oxidizing activity, converting 99.02 % of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol, with the main product yield reaching 97.62 %. In comparison, Co3O4@NFs only achieved 46.01 % substrate conversion and a 43.21 % yield of the main product. Similarly, CuO@NFs only achieved 27.90 % substrate conversion and a 24.45 % yield of the main product. The above data proved that Cu and Co in a bimetallic system were essential to ensure high activity of the material. Figure S2 shows the O2-TPD characterization results of the three materials. The desorption peak at 212°C was attributed to O2 weakly physisorbed on each catalyst surface. In contrast, the desorption peak at 307°C was attributed to strongly chemisorbed O2 [25]. CuCo2O4@NFs showed the strongest weakly physisorbed and strongly chemisorbed O2, which indicated the strongest O2 uptake capacity of the material. Furthermore, the O2 uptake capacity of Co3O4@NFs was observed to be more pronounced than that of CuO@NFs, in accordance with the oxidation outcomes presented in Table 1. This substantiated the assertion that the oxidizing activities of the materials were intimately associated with their oxygen uptake capacities. The reasons for the excellent oxygen uptake capacity of CuCo2O4@NFs were investigated by applying a series of characterization tools. Initially, in the O 1 s high-resolution energy spectra, the three materials could be fitted with characteristic peaks at 530.0, 531.6, and 533.0 eV, corresponding to the lattice oxygen in spinel Co3O4 (M-O), the VO (defects), and the oxygen in physisorbed water molecules (O-H), respectively ( Fig. 2a) [26]. It was evident that the VO level in CuCo2O4@NFs was markedly higher than those in Co3O4@NFs and CuO@NFs. Defects in CuCo2O4@NFs, Co3O4@NFs, and CuO@NFs were more directly probed by EPR. As illustrated in Fig. 2b, a subtle g-factor intensity was observed in CuO@NFs at g = 2.003, indicating fewer defects within this material [27]. The g-factor intensity of CuCo2O4@NFs exhibited a pronounced increase at this point, suggesting that abundant VO structures were successfully incorporated within the nanoflower form. The VO concentration in Co3O4@NFs was similar to that in CuCo2O4@NFs, but its oxidizing activity was much lower. This showed that the VO concentration was not the only factor affecting the oxidizing activity of the material. Lattice dynamics in CuCo2O4@NFs and Co3O4@NFs were analyzed by Raman spectroscopy to explain the reason for the difference in oxidation activities. Both materials contained Co3O4, a cubic spinel oxide with space group Fd3m. It gave rise to five typical active modes in the Raman spectra, as shown in Fig. 2c: A1 g (600–900 cm−1), Eg (400 cm−1), and three F2 g modes (F’ 2 g: 200 cm−1, F’’ 2 g: 450 cm−1, F’’’ 2 g: 580 cm−1) [28]. Among them, the A1 g mode was related to Co3+-O2- stretching in the octahedral CoO6 unit, the Eg mode was related to geometric bending vibrations of O-Co-O, and the F2 g mode is related to Co2+-O2- stretching in the tetrahedral CoO4 geometry [22]. The A1 g peak of CuCo2O4@NFs was evidently shifted to the low frequency region, which was caused by the VO in the material increasing the degree of lattice disorder. The A1 g/F’ 2 g intensity ratio showed the extent to which the octahedral position is occupied. CuCo2O4@NFs has a lower intensity ratio than Co3O4@NFs. This was because Cu doping partly replaced Co in the octahedral position, generating VCo. The specific schematic diagram is shown in Fig. 2d (more characterization of defects in Figures S3 and S4). The above data showed that the synergism of VO and VCo was essential for high activity. Fig. 3a shows that CuCo2O4@NFs, CuCo2O4, and NC@CuCoN x /CF had similar metal ratios. Moreover, XPS mapping indicated that these three materials had analogous elemental compositions (Fig. 3b). However, their oxidizing abilities were quite different (Table 1). The substrate conversion rates of CuCo2O4 and NC@CuCoN x /CF were 67.00 % and 78.55 %, respectively, and the main product yields were 65.00 % and 77.05 %, respectively. O2-TPD showed the O2 uptake of CuCo2O4@NFs to be superior to those of CuCo2O4 and NC@CuCoN x /CF, which was postulated as the reason for the difference in the oxidizing abilities of the three materials (Fig. 3c). The above phenomenon was further analyzed from the perspective of defects, as illustrated in the EPR spectra (Fig. 3d). The peak intensity of CuCo2O4@NFs at a g-factor of 2.003 was highest, which indicated that its VO content was greater than those of CuCo2O4 and NC@CuCoN x /CF. Fig. 3e shows the Raman spectra of the three materials. The intensity ratio of A1 g/F’ 2 g for CuCo2O4@NFs was higher than those of CuCo2O4 and NC@CuCoN x /CF, which indicated that it had the highest VCo content. SEM images showed that CuCo2O4 adopted a lamellar structure, while NC@CuCoN x /CF was in the form of nanosheets (Figure S5). TEM images showed that both materials lacked a cavity structure (Figure S5). It can be reasonably inferred from analysis of their morphologies that the structural features of CuCo2O4 and NC@CuCoN x /CF resulted in relatively limited specific surface areas. This ultimately led to an insufficient area for the exposure of VO and VCo, which in turn affected the O2 uptake capacities of the materials. BET analysis corroborated this hypothesis, with the specific surface area of CuCo2O4@NFs being markedly higher than those of CuCo2O4 and NC@CuCoN x /CF (Fig. 3f). In conclusion, the high activity of CuCo2O4@NFs was attributed to its nanoflower and cavity structures, which increased its specific surface area. The increased surface area allowed the material surface to be inlaid with abundant VO and VCo, which improved its O2 adsorption capacity. 3.3 Investigation of factors affecting the properties of CuCo2O4@NFs The results of the oxidation experiments in Table 2 indicated that the activity of CuCo2O4@NFs was also affected by the metal:2-methylimidazole ratio. At a metal:2-methylimidazole ratio of 1:0.8, the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol reached 76.03 %, accompanied by a phenol yield of 35.87 %. An increase in the ratio of metal:2-methylimidazole to 1:0.9 resulted in a slight enhancement in the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol. Upon reaching a ratio of 1:1.1, the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol and the phenol yield reached the highest values of 99.02 % and 49.50 %, respectively. This suggested that the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol was positively correlated with the metal:2-methylimidazole ratio. However, when the ratio of metal:2-methylimidazole was further increased, it was observed that the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol and the phenol yield began to decrease. Thus, the optimal oxidation performance of the CuCo2O4@NFs composite was achieved at a metal:2-methylimidazole ratio of 1:1.1. The specific reasons why the metal:2-methylimidazole ratio affected the oxidizing properties of the composite were explored by O2-TPD, and the results are shown in Fig. 4a. It can be seen that a metal:2-methylimidazole ratio of 1:1.1 led to the lowest desorption peak temperature, implying that O2 was adsorbed more easily on the surface of the CuCo2O4@NFs composite in this case. The area under the desorption peak was correlated with the oxygen uptake of the material, and integration of the peaks yielded the data plotted in Fig. 4b. The desorption peak reached its maximum at a metal:2-methylimidazole ratio of 1:1.1, corresponding to the optimal oxygen uptake of CuCo2O4@NFs. In conjunction with the oxidation experiments, it was concluded that more O2 was adsorbed to increase the oxidation efficiency at a metal:2-methylimidazole ratio of 1:1.1. SEM images of the CuCo2O4@NFs precursor showed that the particle size increased with increasing metal:2-methylimidazole ratio, reaching a maximum value of 102 nm at a ratio of 1:1.1 (Figure S6). At a ratio of 1:1.2, the particle size decreased to 97 nm. When the ratio was further adjusted to 1:1.3, the particle size decreased to 88 nm. A change in the size of the precursor particles affected the volume of the cavities in CuCo2O4@NFs. In other words, the ratio of metal:2-methylimidazole modulated the volume of the cavities in CuCo2O4@NFs to affect the rate of O2 uptake. TEM images of CuCo2O4@NFs revealed the volume of the cavities within the material at varying metal:2-methylimidazole ratios (Figure S7). Evidently, the cavities all exhibited a rhombic dodecahedral shape, consistent with the shape of the precursor. The variation rule of the cavity volume was consistent with that of the precursor particle size, which confirmed that the metal:2-methylimidazole ratio modulated the cavity volume of CuCo2O4@NFs to affect the oxidation performance. As can be observed in Table 3, the pyrolysis temperature had a significant influence on the properties of CuCo2O4@NFs. At a pyrolysis temperature of 200°C, the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol was observed to be only 60.30 %, with a phenol yield of 24.15 %. As the temperature was increased, the conversion and yield exhibited corresponding increases. At a pyrolysis temperature of 400 °C, the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol reached 99.02 % and the phenol yield reached 49.50 %. At a pyrolysis temperature of 500°C, the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol was reduced to 90.00 %, and the yield of phenol was reduced to 43 %. With a further increase of the pyrolysis temperature to 600°C, the conversion of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol decreased by 58.35 % and the phenol yield decreased by 64.40 % compared to those at 400°C. The results indicated that the CuCo2O4@NFs composite exhibited optimal performance when subjected to pyrolysis at 400°C. The VO contents of CuCo2O4@NFs at different pyrolysis temperatures were explored by EPR characterization, and the results are shown in Fig. 5a. At a pyrolysis temperature of 200°C, the VO content was found to be relatively low. As the pyrolysis temperature was increased, the VO content on the surface of the composite increased, reaching a maximum at 400°C. Raman spectroscopy was employed to elucidate the underlying mechanism responsible for the observed increase in VO content with increasing pyrolysis temperature (Fig. 5b). The lowest vibrational frequency of the A1 g mode at 400°C indicated that the lattice disorder was most pronounced, accompanied by the highest number of VO. Meanwhile, the intensity ratio of A1 g/F’ 2 g was lowest at 400°C, indicating that the material had the most VCo. The abundances of VO and VCo on the surface of the material resulted in a significantly enhanced catalytic activity. However, when the pyrolysis temperature exceeded 400°C, the VO content started to decrease (the vibrational frequency increased). Particularly at 600 °C, the VO content was markedly lower. In order to elucidate the underlying cause of this phenomenon, BET characterization was conducted to examine the influence of pyrolysis temperature on the specific surface area of CuCo2O4@NFs. As illustrated in Fig. 5c, the specific surface area of the material remained largely unchanged at pyrolysis temperatures of 200°C, 300°C, and 400°C. Specific surface area began to decrease at 500°C, and decreased most dramatically at 600°C. It can be concluded that high pyrolysis temperatures had a detrimental effect on the specific surface area of the material. This leads to a decrease in the surface VO and VCo contents, which affected the catalytic performance [31]. The reason for the decrease in specific surface area can be analyzed with reference to the particle size distribution graph presented in Fig. 5d. When the pyrolysis temperature was below 500°C, the average particle size of the material remained relatively constant. However, when the temperature reached 600°C, the average particle size showed a sudden increase. A TEM image of CuCo2O4@NFs after pyrolysis at 600°C showed that the structure of the material had collapsed. This indicated that a high pyrolysis temperature resulted in the decomposition of organic ligands as well as pore collapse in the composite, which reduced the specific surface area and provides a smaller anchoring space for the production of VO and VCo. These results were consistent with those of the oxidation experiments, which indicated that the surface of CuCo2O4@NFs had the highest abundance of VO and VCo at a pyrolysis temperature of 400 °C. This led to an increase in the amount of adsorbed O2 and an improvement in reaction efficiency. 3.4 Kinetic analysis and theoretical computational studies In order to investigate the mechanism by which VO and VCo enhanced the properties of CuCo2O4@NFs, simulations of the defect-free structures of Co3O4, Co3O4-VO, Co3O4-VCo, and Co3O4-VO/VCo were performed. Structural optimization of the four models revealed that both VO and VCo lead to lattice distortion ( Fig. 6a). In comparison to defect-free Co3O4, the Cotet-O bond length in Co3O4-VO was markedly extended, while the Cooct-O bond length in Co3O4-VCo was considerably contracted. This suggested that VO had the capacity to extend the Cotet-O bond length, whereas VCo acted to shorten the Cooct-O bond length (Cotet, divalent cobalt ion occupying a tetrahedral void; Cooct, trivalent cobalt ion occupying an octahedral void) [22]. The bond length modulation implied a tuning of the local Co-O coordination environment, which played a crucial role in determining the catalytic activity. The adsorption of O2 and the formation of *OO were decisive steps in the oxidative cleavage of 2-phenoxy-1-phenylethanol. That is to say, the greater the adsorption energy of O2 and the lower the adsorption energy of *OO, the more favorable the reaction (minimum ΔG *OO–ΔG *O2 value). Therefore, the adsorption energies of O2 and *OO on different active sites in defect-free Co3O4, Co3O4-VO, Co3O4-VCo, and Co3O4-VO/VCo were calculated. The adsorption energy of O2 on defect-free Co3O4 was 0.60 eV, and that of *OO was 2.41 eV (Fig. 6b). It was noteworthy that the adsorption energies of O2 and *OO on Co3O4-VO were 1.38 and 2.20 eV, respectively, while on Co3O4-VCo they were 0.65 and 1.74 eV, respectively (Fig. 6c, d). Evidently, the presence of VO enhanced the adsorption energy of O2 and the presence of VCo reduced the adsorption energy of *OO. In other words, VO facilitated the adsorption of O2, while VCo inhibited the adsorption of *OO and promotes the dissociation of free radicals. As illustrated in Fig. 6e, the Co3O4-VO/VCo sample exhibited the lowest value of G *OO–ΔG *O2, implying that it should be most favorable for the reaction. The evidence demonstrated that the optimal performance of CuCo2O4@NFs composites was attributable to both VO and VCo. Notably, the G *OO–ΔG *O2 value for Co3O4-VCo was larger than that for Co3O4-VO, which indicated that VO promoted the reaction more strongly than VCo. An understanding of the electronic properties inherent to the four materials was facilitated by their densities of states (DOS) (Figure S8). It was established that the Fermi energy level (Ef) was situated between the valence band (Bv) and the conduction band (Bc). A narrower gap resulted in a more favorable environment for electron leaps. The band gaps were 1.77 eV for defect-free Co3O4 and 0.73 eV for Co3O4-VO, which clearly showed that the presence of VO reduced the band gap spacing. The band gap of Co3O4-VCo was 1.65 eV, which was narrower than that of defect-free Co3O4 and wider than that of Co3O4-VO. This suggested that VCo facilitated electron leaps, but the promotion was considerably less effective than in the presence of VO [32]. Co3O4-VO/VCo had the smallest band gap of 0.67 eV, which indicated that the two vacancy structures synergistically improved electron mobility. This ensured the high activity of CuCo2O4@NFs. The DOS contributions of the four structures were primarily derived from the 3d orbitals of Co and the 2p orbitals of O. It was noteworthy that these orbitals exhibited the highest degree of overlap in Co3O4-VO/VCo, which indicated the strongest bonding ability between the O2 molecule and the adsorption site [33]. This provided a further rationale for the high activity of CuCo2O4@NFs. The activation pathways of O2 and the types of reactive oxygen species were analyzed by EPR. A comparison of the fingerprint peaks revealed that Fig. 6f corresponded to the superoxide radical peak, Fig. 6g corresponds to the singlet oxygen peak, and Fig. 6h corresponds to the hydroxyl radical peak. This indicated that these three reactive oxygen species were produced during the reaction process [34]. Moreover, in situ FTIR characterization was carried out to reveal the activation process of O2 on the catalyst surface (Figure S9). The peaks at around 900 and 1640 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of peroxide, and that at around 1100 cm−1 corresponded to the stretching vibration of superoxide (adsorbed state of ·O2) [35]. In the initial stage of the reaction, the stretching vibration peak of superoxide reached its highest intensity. As the reaction proceeded, this peak was attenuated. The stretching vibration peak of peroxide was not immediately apparent at the start of the reaction, but gradually intensified as the reaction proceeds. The variations in the peaks indicated that O2 was adsorbed at the active site in the initial stage of the reaction, whereupon it lost an electron and is converted into superoxide radical for the purpose of oxygen activation. In conjunction with the aforementioned EPR characterization and DFT calculations, it was determined that the process entailed the adsorption and transformation of three pivotal reaction intermediates, namely superoxide radical, hydroxyl radical, and singlet oxygen. The proposed mechanism is schematically illustrated in Fig. 6i. The four principal processes depicted in the figure are as follows: (I) adsorption of O2 at the active site and conversion into superoxide radical; (II, Ⅲ) attack of the substrate -OH fragment by superoxide radical to form hydroxyl radical with the introduction of an oxygen-containing group at the Cβ-site; (IV) introduction of this oxygen-containing group reduces the β-O-4 bond dissociation energy, generating the product, which can then desorb from the active site. Fig. 6j shows Gibbs free energy diagrams of surface-adsorbed intermediates on defect-free Co3O4, Co3O4-VO, Co3O4-VCo, and Co3O4-VO/VCo structures. Combined with Figure S10, it was seen that the ΔG *OO–ΔG *O2 value of the Co3O4-VO/VCo structure was 0.33 eV, much lower than those of defect-free Co3O4 (1.58 eV), Co3O4-VO (0.95 eV), and Co3O4-VCo (1.12 eV). It was noteworthy that the conversion of O2 to *OO was typically regarded as a potential rate-determining step, whereby lower ΔG *OO–ΔG *O2 values were more conducive to progress of the reaction. According to the magnitude of the values, the synergistic effect of VO and VCo greatly improved the oxidation efficiency, which is consistent with the density of states results. 3.5 Recyclability of CuCo2O4@NFs A series of recycling experiments was conducted to assess the reusability of CuCo2O4@NFs, and the specific results are displayed in Table 4. The fresh catalyst converted 99.02 % of the substrate with a phenol yield of 49.05 %. After three cycles, there was no significant change in substrate conversion or phenol yield. After the fifth cycle, the substrate conversion was observed to be 95.93 %, which was 3.12 % lower than the initial value. Accordingly, the phenol yield exhibited a reduction of 4.38 %. Overall, the CuCo2O4@NFs remained highly active over five cycles, indicating that the active components of the material were stable and were not susceptible to deactivation during oxidation. Characterization by XPS, XAFS, BET, SEM, and TEM revealed the specific reason for the high recyclability of CuCo2O4@NFs. Fig. 7(a–f) show the O 1 s spectra of CuCo2O4@NFs catalysts after different numbers of cycles. The peak area of VO in the fresh catalyst was 51.6 %, and this remained essentially unchanged after four cycles. This indicated that the VO content in the catalyst did not decrease appreciably. After five cycles, the VO peak area proportion was 47.5 %, a decrease of 7.9 % compared to that for the fresh catalyst, consistent with the slight decrease in catalytic activity. The pore structure parameters in Table S1 showed that after five cycles, the specific surface area of the catalyst had decreased slightly, while the pore size had increased slightly. This may be explained by the fact that during the cycling experiments, agitation or high temperature caused the small pores to aggregate into large pores and collapse, leading to a decrease in specific surface area. This, in turn, reduced the anchoring space for VO, to the detriment of catalytic activity. Figure S11 shows the X-ray absorption near-edge spectra (XANES) of a CuCo2O4@NFs catalyst after different numbers of cycles. The white line peaks of both the fresh and recycled catalysts were observed at approximately 7730.4 eV, showing that there was no change in the valence state of Co [36]. Given that the presence of VCo altered the metal valence, the XANES data supported the assertion that the quantity of VCo remained unaltered after repeated cycles. As previously demonstrated, the factors that affected the activity of CuCo2O4@NFs catalysts were the size of the cavity structure as well as the levels of VO and VCo. SEM images of both the fresh catalyst and those recycled many times showed essentially the same nanoflower structure (Fig. 7 g), indicating that the CuCo2O4@NFs catalyst exhibited structural stability. The average diameter of the nanoflowers was approximately 127 nm. Furthermore, TEM images of both the fresh catalyst and those recycled many times revealed the same cavity structure with a rhombic dodecahedron shape, of diameter about 102 nm in all cases. This again proved the structural stability of the catalyst (Fig. 7 h). The number of defects as well as the apparent morphology of CuCo2O4@NFs did not change significantly after several cycles. However, its specific surface area was slightly reduced due to the altered pore structure, which affected its activity. Nevertheless, the variations in specific surface area and activity of the CuCo2O4@NFs catalyst were minor. From an overall viewpoint, the CuCo2O4@NFs catalyst exhibited excellent reusability. 4 Conclusions Surface VO- and VCo-enriched CuCo2O4@NFs hollow nanoflower material has been applied for oxidative cleavage in lignin β-O-4 bond model compounds. The experimental results demonstrated that CuCo2O4@NFs provided excellent oxidative cleavage activity. Characterization has shown that nanoflower and cavity structures significantly increased the specific surface area and provided sufficient exposure space for active sites. The synergy of VO and VCo enhanced the O2 uptake capacity of the material and promoted its activation. DFT calculations have shown that VO extended the Cotet-O bond lengths and that VCo shortened the Cooct-O bond lengths, leading to lattice distortion and altering the Co-O coordination environment. Specifically, the increase in Cotet-O bond length promoted O2 adsorption, while the shortening of Cooct-O bond length promoted *OO desorption, which improved the rate of the rate-limiting step. The two vacancy structures synergistically reduced the gap between the Fermi energy level and the conduction band, which improved the electron-leaping ability. Furthermore, the oxidation activity of CuCo2O4@NFs was enhanced by adjusting the metal:2-methylimidazole ratio to optimize the specific surface area and by controlling the annealing temperature to maximize the number of two-vacancy structures. The optimized material converted 99.02 % of the β-O-4 model compound and the phenol yield was 49.50 %. Finally, recycling experiments were conducted to confirm the excellent reusability of CuCo2O4@NFs. This work presented a viable approach for modulating the product-directed Cα-H removal reaction and generating the corresponding aldehydes or ketones. coredata.dc:description: A hollow nanoflower material CuCo2O4@NFs with abundant oxygen vacancies (VO) and cobalt vacancies (VCo) was prepared by a simple method. The novel material CuCo2O4@NFs showed excellent oxidation activity, cleaving the β-O-4 bond in lignin model compounds. Conversion of the substrate was as high as 99.02 %, and the yield of the main product, phenol, reached 49.50 %. Structural analysis showed that the petal and cavity form of the material increased its specific surface area, which facilitated its full contact with O2 molecules. Moreover, the VO generated by lattice oxygen detachment during annealing favor the adsorption of O2, and the VCo generated through lattice distortion induced by Cu-metal doping promoted the detachment of oxygen intermediates. The synergy of these two defects improved the rate of the rate-limiting step. Density functional theory calculations revealed that the synergistic effect of VO and VCo narrowed the gap between the Fermi energy levels and the d-band center, thereby enhancing electron mobility. Finally, excellent recyclability of CuCo2O4@NFs was confirmed through cycling experiments. The application of this material provided technical support for the efficient cracking of lignin into high-value-added chemicals and realized the effective utilization of woody biomass resources.
coredata.dc:title: Preparation of CuCo2O4@NFs nanoflower material with abundant VO/VCo: An excellent catalyst for oxidative breakage of the β-O-4 bond of lignin
